author.location: Bridgnorth, Shropshire. I am a member :o)

posts.content:
Took my 67 Dudley cooker out for a good summer clean & get all the rust out that seems never endlessly falling off from the burners grill etc.

I turned it over to look at the grill part, as I am contemplating replacing the grill 'elements' as they are a bit holey!
Has anyone ever replaced these expanded metal parts, they are just clipped into the frame.
I read a thread, after a search on the internet, that most static caravan grills are the same and these grills regularly get replaced by a corgi gas engineer, so they, or similar, must be available I guess - But I can't find any online either that or I need to make some...
I thought I would just turn them around, but they are SO brittle that they fall apart at the slightest touch.
Do you think just normal mild steel expanded sheet or galv? I thinking galv is a BAD idea for my toast health - hahaha
Anyone ever done similar?





Secondly - on the burner tubes there are some stainless spring clips that can rotate around the burner pipes opening & closing the pipe to air - are these critical (as my center one (grill) is missing completely and the other two were fully open? - I can't quite see what these achieve? Is it to mix gas/air at the right rate?





Cheers All

The grill mesh is just ordinary mild steel mesh Ted. Don't use galvanised - zinc vapour is highly toxic so won't improve toast. The air supply clips are there to cope with different gases. The stove was designed for calor gas - propane I think - which needed slightly less air input. Most of these stoves are now used on butane so need the air inlets fully open. I would always use them fully open because it reduces the chances of carbon monoxide being produced due to incomplete combustion.

author.location: Bridgnorth, Shropshire. I am a member :o)

posts.content:
OK - as I'm away next week in Devon - thought I'd have a go at fixing my grill - popped into B & Q to see if they had anything like the expanded mesh stuff Dudley used on the grill element - they did actually have a selection - so I bought the closest I could find.... (made sure I got the steel version as they did the same size in aluminium!) - It was about Â£8 I think.



Its the same 'pitch' ie the holes are expanded to the same size, but once out of the packet its a slightly lighter weight mesh, the original stuff was a bit thicker, but this was the closest match that B & Q had on the shelf - so I thought I'd give it a go...

Thsi pic shows a comparison - you can see the difference in the gauge of metal - this photo seems to make it look worse than it is - but the new stuff is a bit thinner for sure...



So after a bit of snipping with the tin snips I have fashioned some replacements - of course not content with just a straight replacement I have gone the extra mile to see if I can improve the grill performance and 'modded' the grill element to be much larger than the original - time will tell if this has worked..LOL



So I'll keep you posted on how my turbocharged grill now performs - it may all melt onto my toast, as 'toast a la molten steel' or I may have just revolutionised the dudley cooker grilling capability (I suspect & fear the former!)

I'll let you know the outcome! - CHEERS

Good Luck Ted, when are you off on your trip?

May join you at the Dubs at the Beach event if I get a break from work sorted.

It's that VW Bus meet at Kinver tonight if you've run out of polish yet?

Hi Ted
Richard said you will be coming to DDF at Bicton? If so SSVC camping is right next to the entrance on left hand side. You'll see various split buses camped up - ask the guys and girls on the gate if you are not sure. See you there. We can try out the new improved grill
Brian

posts.content:
Just an update - have used the new improved 'turbo grill' in anger now for a few days and it does seem much better (and its not melted - yet!)
So toast is back on the menu - woohoo!

Also twiddled the burner air control rings - as Brian (BJ1) had said - I had to have them fully open on Blue Calor Gaz or it was very yellow and smoky - cheers for the advice.
